inlineContent.text: Materials are what define the appearance of the objects in 3D scenes. Materials can be simple, just a single color, or they can use images. We might apply a wood texture to the model of a chair or map an image of bricks to a wall. Materials can also be quite sophisticated. They might use animation to look like rippling water or change appearance based on viewing angle. Like iridescent sparkle of mother of pearl. Materials can even modify the geometry of the objects they are applied to.
Materials in visionOS use Physically Based Rendering (PBR) to represent physical properties of real world objects, for example, how metallic or how rough an object looks.
Materials consist of one or more
shaders
. These are programs that do the actual work of computing the appearance of their material.
With RealityKit 2 for iOS and iPadOS, Apple introduced CustomMaterial. Shaders in CustomMaterial are hand coded in Metal.
Surface shaders
operate on the PBR attributes of models.
Geometry modifiers
operate on the geometry of objects.
In xrOS, a new type of material is been introduced:
ShaderGraphMaterial
This is the exclusive way of creating custom materials for visionOS
. Based on the open standard
Supports 2 main types of shaders:
Physically Based
and
Custom
Physically based shader is intended for simpler use cases (e.g. constant, non-changing values)
Custom is intended for precise and custom control over 3D objects (e.g. animation, geometry modifiers, special effects, etc.

ShaderGraphMaterial supports two main types of shaders, which we call Physically Based and Custom. Physically Based is a basic PBR shader. we configure this shader by providing constant, nonchanging values, like colors or images, for each property. Custom shaders, on the other hand, give us precise and custom control over the appearance of 3D objects.
Custom shaders can incorporate animation, adjust object‚Äôs geometry, and create special effects on the surface of the object, like a sparkly paint look.
we can build ShaderGraphMaterials using the Shader Graph editor right inside Reality Composer Pro.
Materials in xrOS can be created using Reality Composer Pro
For an introduction to the Reality composer pro app before starting with materials, please watch:
The session will use the Yosemite Valley model and apply a topographical map appearance to it. All the objects we don‚Äôt need for this session have been hidden using the Deactivate command.

Let‚Äôs add a topography feature. We‚Äôll add a material showing the topography of our model by displaying contour lines along the slope of the terrain. It‚Äôll look similar to the topographical map that we might have come across when planning a hike.

Let‚Äôs create a custom material containing a shader that will draw contour lines on our terrain. We want to draw lines on our terrain through all the areas that have the same elevation, like in this diagram. This blue line, for example, shows all points on the terrain at 1000 meters of elevation. Seen from above, it will look something like the diagram on the right.
Add a material by clicking the
icon inside the Project Browser. Under Materials, notice our two shader types: Physically Based and Custom. Choose Custom.
This reveals the Shader Graph of our editor.

New custom shaders start with two nodes, the surface node in purple and the outputs node in blue. the material‚Äôs active surface is the one connected to the custom surface input of the outputs node. The inputs on the surface are how we set our shader‚Äôs physically based, or PBR, parameters. Base color, for example.

Let‚Äôs give the material a descriptive name. TopographyMaterial sounds good. An important step is to assign our new material to our Yosemite Valley model. Select it in the project hierarchy. In the inspector, under Material Bindings, choose TopographyMaterial from the Binding menu.

Notice the model changes from color to a simple gray. Our material is working, but it doesn‚Äôt do anything interesting yet. Select TopographyMaterial from the hierarchy to return to the Shader Graph editor. We‚Äôll connect some nodes to our surface inputs to draw stripes on our model in the right places.

We‚Äôll illustrate how our material will work with this example terrain. We need our material to decide where to draw topographical lines based on its location on our model. So first we‚Äôll add a position node to our material. This node returns our rendering position in 3D space. We‚Äôre only interested in the height of position, so we‚Äôll also add a node called separate to extract just the position‚Äôs Y-coordinate. Separate returns the Y-coordinate position, which increases with terrain height.

Let‚Äôs add these first two nodes to our material in Reality Composer Pro. Double-click on the background of the editor to add nodes. This brings up the New Node picker. we can browse through the list of all the available nodes, or search for nodes by name or keyword. Let‚Äôs type ‚Äúposition‚Äù and select the Position node from the list to insert it into our shader. Position outputs the location in 3D space where the material is being rendered.

Our material varies with height, so let‚Äôs add a separate node to extract the Y component of position. Double-click the background to bring up the New Node picker again and add a Separate 3 node. To make connections in the editor, just click and drag from node outputs to node inputs like this.

These two nodes combined give us the height of the terrain. Next, we‚Äôll take the output of the separate node and pass it to a modulo node. Modulo gives the remainder of dividing two values. We‚Äôll use modulo to divide height by our desired topographical line spacing. The result looks like this. we can see height has been divided into bands. The height values inside each range start at 0 and increase to that range‚Äôs height. This will be important for our next step.

Let‚Äôs add the modulo node to our material in Reality Composer Pro. Instead of double-clicking to add a node and then connecting it, we can drag a new connection to an empty space to create a node that‚Äôs already connected in one step. In the New Node picker, type ‚Äúmodulo‚Äù and click to insert a Modulo node. Modulo has two inputs. The first is the dividend and the second is the divisor. we can conveniently set constant values on inputs in the inspector instead of connecting nodes. In the inspector, change the second argument to 0.1. This is the divisor and sets the width of our height ranges.

We have just one more step to go before we can see our output. We‚Äôll use an ifgreater node to determine where our repeating values fall in narrow height bands on our terrain. The ifgreater node will return a value representing one of the two band colors we see on screen, depending on the result of a comparison. When the height is greater than our shader topographical line width, we‚Äôll choose a background color. And where the height falls within our desired line width, we‚Äôll choose our topography line color.

Let‚Äôs add the ifgreater node to our material and see the results. We want to compare the result of the modulo node to a value we choose for our topographical line width. So we‚Äôll add an ifgreater node to do that comparison. Ifgreater compares its two inputs and returns one value when its first input is greater than its second input, and a different value when the first input is less than its second input. This ifgreater node is set to output floating point values, but we want to choose between two colors, one for our terrain and one for our topographical lines. In the inspector, under Type, change this node to output RGB. Next, let‚Äôs pick our two colors.
In the inspector, we‚Äôll click on the color picker next to True Result and set our terrain color. Let‚Äôs use white.
Let‚Äôs leave the False Result, which is our topographical line color, set to black.

This will give us a lot of contrast with our white terrain. 0.002 is a good value for line width, so in the inspector, we‚Äôll set the comparison value to 0.002. we‚Äôll connect the ifgreater node‚Äôs output to our surface‚Äôs Diffuse Color input. Awesome, now our material is setting the color at every point on our terrain and we‚Äôve made a topographical lines material.
This section jumps right into a walk-through tutorial on applying topography lines to a geographical diorama. Starts at
Important!
make sure we assign our new material to our model in the hierarchy. we do this by selecting custom material from the model‚Äôs Material Binding dropdown in the inspector
Node graphs help simplify complex materials and let we create our own nodes to reuse parts of graphs.
We‚Äôll use node graphs to give a material a real topographical map look. Let‚Äôs add a second set of lines between the current lines of our material.
Here‚Äôs what our material looks like so far.
And here‚Äôs what it will look like when we add our subdivisions.
We‚Äôll start with the four nodes in our material that draw our topographical lines.

Then we‚Äôll compose a node graph from them. This will combine our four nodes into a single node. Finally, we‚Äôll create an instance of our node graph to reuse its functionality. One node graph will draw our original set of lines, and the instance of it will draw our second set of lines.
Let‚Äôs go back into Reality Composer Pro and build it.
Here is our topographical lines shader again. Drag to select these four nodes that compute the colors for our lines and where to draw them.

After selecting them, right-click and choose Compose Node Graph. Now the nodes appear as a single node that I can use inside other graphs. Let‚Äôs assign a descriptive name to our new node. Let‚Äôs call it Lines.
We‚Äôll create a copy of this node graph to draw our second set of lines. For this, we‚Äôll create an instance using the Create Instance command in the hierarchy.
Instances are live copies that adopt any changes made to the original node graph. We‚Äôll return to our material by selecting it. Let‚Äôs call our new instance SecondaryLines.
We want our node graph and its instance to draw lines with different spacings and colors, so we‚Äôll add two inputs, called Spacing and Color, to our original node graph to control these properties.
Let‚Äôs edit our original node graph by double-clicking it.
we add inputs and outputs to our node graph in the inspector. First let‚Äôs add an input called Spacing and set its type to Float.
We‚Äôll also add an input called Color to control our topography line color. Set the type of the input to Color3.
I‚Äôll connect these to the right places in our graph.

Let‚Äôs go back to our material by selecting it in the project hierarchy. Notice that our node graph now has the two inputs we created, and that our instance inherited these two new inputs. On the original Lines node graph, set spacing to the values we chose before. And let‚Äôs choose a smaller spacing and a lighter color for our instance node graph.

The last step is to combine the outputs from our original and instance node graphs. I‚Äôve conveniently chosen grayscale colors for both node graphs, so we can combine their colors using a multiply node.
Quick Tips
Multi-select any set of nodes and right-click > Compose Node Graph to make reusable node components
In the project hierarchy, right-click > Create Instance to create an instance of our node graph
Add inputs and outputs to our node graph in the inspector
Instances
of node graphs are live copies that
adopt any changes made to the original node graph
. They inherit inputs and outputs added to the original node graph it points to.
These are a feature of custom materials we can use to modify our models in real time.
We‚Äôll replace our static terrain model and recreate it using geometry modifiers and height data.

Then we‚Äôll extend our geometry modifier to dynamically animate between two different terrains: Yosemite Valley and Catalina Island, California. When we‚Äôre done, we‚Äôll have a dynamic terrain material that can animate between our two different locations. Let‚Äôs see how this is done. All the shaders we‚Äôve looked at so far are surface shaders. These are shaders that set the physically based, or PBR, attributes for each pixel of our model as it‚Äôs rendered. Geometry modifiers are similar to surface shaders, but operate on the geometry of our objects instead. In fact, we build them right in the same editor in Reality Composer Pro.
Reminder
Surface shaders operate on the PBR attributes while Geometry modifiers operate on the geometry of objects.
This section jumps right into a walk-through tutorial on applying heightmaps to generate geometry, and animating between those heightmaps. Starts at

Here is an overview of the geometry modifier we‚Äôre going to build that will create a terrain of Yosemite Valley using its height map data. We‚Äôll start with a flat disk model, which contains some plain geometry. This will be our base surface. Next we‚Äôll use our terrain height data, which is 2D data about the height at each location of our model, and use a geometry modifier to raise the terrain by the correct amount. This will result in the terrain we want.

Once shown the basic version, we‚Äôll demonstrate a version that takes two sets of terrain heights and uses those to animate between our two locations of interest, Yosemite Valley and Catalina Island.
Here‚Äôs another view. We‚Äôll start with a flat model, and our geometry modifier will move its vertices vertically using data from a 2D height map like this.
The first thing we‚Äôll do is use the Deactivate command to hide the prebuilt Yosemite Valley model.
We‚Äôll generate the same Yosemite Valley model, but this time using our geometry modifier. I‚Äôll start with a flat disk model in my Project Browser.
We can bring it in by dragging it into the Root entity in the project hierarchy.

Here we created a new material named DynamicTerrainMaterial and assigned it to the disk. Let‚Äôs get to work on our geometry modifier. In the Shader Graph editor, we‚Äôll need a geometry modifier surface. We‚Äôll add this to our material alongside our PBR surface. We drag a connection from the Custom Geometry Modifier input of our output node and choose Geometry Modifier from the New Node UI.
Let‚Äôs first apply our Yosemite Valley image to our surface. To read image data, we‚Äôll use an image node.
In the inspector, let‚Äôs assign our Yosemite Valley image to the image node‚Äôs Filename input.
Things look a bit funny since the terrain is flat, but we‚Äôre going to fix that now.

We‚Äôll need the height data for our valley. It‚Äôs in an image file which contains height values instead of color data. Since this data is in an image, we‚Äôll read it by adding another image node. Now assign our Yosemite Valley EXR image containing our height data to this new image node‚Äôs Filename input.

Geometry modifiers can move the vertices of our model in any direction, but we‚Äôre only interested in moving them vertically, so let‚Äôs insert a Combine 3 node to create a 3D vector with only the Y component set. Now connect this to the GeometryModifier surface‚Äôs Model Position Offset input, and boom, our flat model has been transformed into Yosemite Valley.

There‚Äôs one more step we need to take. When we move our vertices, we‚Äôll also need to set the surface normal vectors of our model to match our new terrain shape. There are ways to compute these from the height data, but today we‚Äôre going to use an image that contains precomputed normals for this geometry. Let‚Äôs create another image node to read the normals.

Since these are precomputed, we‚Äôll connect them directly to our surface shader‚Äôs normal input for better accuracy. Our surface expects normals to have values between -1 and 1, but the normals in our image are between 0 and 1. I‚Äôve remapped the values from the image using a remap node.

Now we‚Äôve created the terrain from a flat geometry using height data. Next, let‚Äôs make our diorama dynamic and add the ability to morph from one terrain to another. In this case, we‚Äôll add an animated transition to change Yosemite Valley to Catalina Island. To achieve this, we‚Äôll first add another set of image nodes to our existing geometry shader. The nodes contain the heights, colors, and normals for our Catalina Island terrain. Then we‚Äôll add mix nodes to blend between these two sets of heights, normals, and colors. Finally, we‚Äôll connect a value to our mix nodes to control blending between our two sets of data.
Let‚Äôs build this in Reality Composer Pro now. OK, here‚Äôs our material so far.
Let‚Äôs add another set of image nodes containing the same data ‚Äì heights, colors, and normals ‚Äì for Catalina Island instead of Yosemite Valley.
Next we‚Äôll add some mix nodes to blend between our two colors, heights, and normals.

Finally let‚Äôs connect a 0 to 1 constant to our mix nodes, which will control which terrain is shown. we‚Äôll notice when I set my mixing constant to 1, the terrain shows Catalina Island. When I set the mixing constant to 0, we see Yosemite Valley.

Now that we have a material that can transition between our two different terrains, let‚Äôs make this transition progress value changeable from our Swift code. We‚Äôll use the Promote command to convert our progress value into an input on our material.

Inputs on materials become properties of the material that can be accessed from the Swift code. Now our material is ready to be used in our Dioramas Swift app. Here‚Äôs the final version, which combines our topography lines and our dynamic terrain. This version has some additional refinements, like anti-aliased topography lines and ambient occlusion maps, all added using Shader Graph.
Check those out in the sample for this session.
Missing anything? Corrections?

metadata.title: Explore materials in Reality Composer Pro

abstract.text: Learn how Reality Composer Pro can help you alter the appearance of your 3D objects using RealityKit materials. We‚Äôll introduce you to MaterialX and physically-based (PBR) shaders, show you how to design dynamic materials using the shader graph editor, and explore adding custom inputs to a material so that you can control it in your visionOS app.

WWDC23-10202-yosemiteModel2.alt: the Yosemite Valley model in Reality Composer Pro

abstract.text: Find out how you can take control of RealityKit rendering to improve the look and feel of your apps and games on visionOS. Discover how you can customize lighting, add grounding shadows, and control tone mapping for your content. We‚Äôll also go over best practices for two key treatments on the platform: rasterization rate maps and dynamic content scaling.

titleInlineContent.text: Work with Reality Composer Pro content in Xcode

https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/.title: Work with Reality Composer Pro content in Xcode

abstract.text: Discover how to easily compose, edit, and preview 3D content with Reality Composer Pro. Follow along as we explore this developer tool by setting up a new project, composing scenes, adding particle emitters and audio, and even previewing content on device.

doc://WWDCNotes/documentation/WWDCNotes/.title: Work with Reality Composer Pro content in Xcode

abstract.text: Learn how to bring content from Reality Composer Pro to life in Xcode. We‚Äôll show you how to load 3D scenes into Xcode, integrate your content with your code, and add interactivity to your app. We‚Äôll also share best practices and tips for using these tools together in your development workflow.
Xcode 15, Swift 5.9, iOS 17, macOS 14 (Sonoma), tvOS 17, visionOS 1, watchOS 10.

abstract.text: Session notes shared by the community for the community.

Discover the latest updates to Universal Scene Description (USD) on Apple platforms and learn how you can deliver great 3D content for your apps, games, and websites. Get to know USD for visionOS, explore MaterialX shaders and color management, and find out about some of the other improvements to the USD ecosystem.

doc://WWDCNotes/documentation/WWDCNotes/.title: Build great games for spatial computing

abstract.text: Find out how you can develop great gaming experiences for visionOS. We‚Äôll share some of the key building blocks that help you create games for this platform, explore how your experiences can fluidly move between levels of immersion, and provide a roadmap for exploring ARKit, RealityKit, Reality Composer Pro, Unity, Metal, and Compositor.

WWDC23-10202-yosemiteModelTopographic.alt: the Yosemite Valley model finished version in Reality Composer Pro

doc://WWDCNotes/documentation/WWDCNotes/.title: Optimize app power and performance for spatial computing

abstract.text: Learn how you can create powerful apps and games for visionOS by optimizing for performance and efficiency. We‚Äôll cover the unique power characteristics of the platform, explore building a performance plan, and share some of the tools and strategies to test and optimize your apps.
